story:
Who We Are:

Established in 2010, the Memorial Cup was founded by Santos FC and Lara Media Services (www.laramedia.com) to further their commitment to Oregon's Latinos. Now in its fourth year, the Cup is a non-profit event that provides an opportunity for youths ages 5-17 to compete in an organized tournament.

Soccer = Passion:

In Latino culture, soccer is a passion cultivated from a young age. We remember gathering together with friends and family to watch the big game on TV or simply kick around in the backyard. Families who come to the United States stay connected to their culture through soccer. For many of them, it is a dream for them to see their children playing this beloved sport. Unfortunately, for many students the entrance fee for these tournaments is prohibitively high.

The Memorial cup gives kids the chance to participate in a tournament that is inexpensive and accessible, unlike a lot of league tournaments that are unavailable to the Latino leagues due to a lack of financial resources. It shows these kids and their families that all things are possible. The Memorial Cup is the only affordable soccer tournament that specifically welcomes Latino Soccer clubs and recreational teams to compete.

The Impact:

The Memorial Cup is the Premiere Latino Soccer tournament in Oregon. In 2012, over 50 teams’ participated and over 5,000 people came out in support. The tournament itself promotes self-esteem, leadership, discipline, and healthy attitudes for people of all ages. Above all, it gives kids a chance to see the power they have within themselves to do extraordinary things.

This event brings families together and connects them to the community at large. For many people, this weekend isn't just a soccer tournament -- it's an opportunity for community groups, government agencies, and businesses to break down barriers and gain access to higher education, health, and leadership opportunities.

What We Need:

With only a few months left before the tournament, we are looking for donations that can help go towards the following areas:

-Park and Event Rental Fees. In order for the event to take place, we need money to pay for the cost of renting fields for the teams to play on.

This year we hope to hold the Cup once again at Memorial Park in Wilsonville, the City’s oldest and largest park. The site contains all of the formal athletic fields owned by the City, which are heavily used by local leagues. We will need money to go towards field rentals so multiple teams can play at once.

-Referees. What's a soccer match without a good referee? In order to hire experienced referees to oversee the games, we need to raise enough funds to pay them for their time and effort over the Memorial Day weekend. These fees are determined per team, per day and with your help, we can help fill all the open slots for the weekend!

-Trophies and medals for the teams. For many teams, the opportunity to participate is the ultimate prize, but we love to reward teams for their excellence and skill. Help us purchase trophies and medals to present to winning teams throughout the weekend, giving students an opportunity to go for the gold and achieve so much more than they could've possibly imagined.

-Promotional Materials. The publicity team at Lara Media wants to spread the word about the Memorial Cup all around Oregon and to do that we need to design and purchase flyers, posters and other promotional materials.

-Water for teams and volunteers.

 Other Ways You Can Help:

Donations of the following would be greatly appreciated: Flats of bottled water, soccer balls, food for volunteers, prizes for the children, or your time! Those interested in volunteering should send a message to contact@laramedia.com.
story_txt:
Who We Are:
Established in 2010, the Memorial Cup was founded by Santos FC and Lara Media Services (www.laramedia.com) to further their commitment to Oregon's Latinos. Now in its fourth year, the Cup is a non-profit event that provides an opportunity for youths ages 5-17 to compete in an organized tournament.
Soccer = Passion:
In Latino culture, soccer is a passion cultivated from a young age. We remember gathering together with friends and family to watch the big game on TV or simply kick around in the backyard. Families who come to the United States stay connected to their culture through soccer. For many of them, it is a dream for them to see their children playing this beloved sport. Unfortunately, for many students the entrance fee for these tournaments is prohibitively high.
The Memorial cup gives kids the chance to participate in a tournament that is inexpensive and accessible, unlike a lot of league tournaments that are unavailable to the Latino leagues due to a lack of financial resources. It shows these kids and their families that all things are possible. The Memorial Cup is the only affordable soccer tournament that specifically welcomes Latino Soccer clubs and recreational teams to compete.
The Impact:
The Memorial Cup is the Premiere Latino Soccer tournament in Oregon. In 2012, over 50 teams’ participated and over 5,000 people came out in support. The tournament itself promotes self-esteem, leadership, discipline, and healthy attitudes for people of all ages. Above all, it gives kids a chance to see the power they have within themselves to do extraordinary things.
This event brings families together and connects them to the community at large. For many people, this weekend isn't just a soccer tournament -- it's an opportunity for community groups, government agencies, and businesses to break down barriers and gain access to higher education, health, and leadership opportunities.
What We Need:
With only a few months left before the tournament, we are looking for donations that can help go towards the following areas:
-Park and Event Rental Fees. In order for the event to take place, we need money to pay for the cost of renting fields for the teams to play on.
This year we hope to hold the Cup once again at Memorial Park in Wilsonville, the City’s oldest and largest park. The site contains all of the formal athletic fields owned by the City, which are heavily used by local leagues. We will need money to go towards field rentals so multiple teams can play at once.
-Referees. What's a soccer match without a good referee? In order to hire experienced referees to oversee the games, we need to raise enough funds to pay them for their time and effort over the Memorial Day weekend. These fees are determined per team, per day and with your help, we can help fill all the open slots for the weekend!
-Trophies and medals for the teams. For many teams, the opportunity to participate is the ultimate prize, but we love to reward teams for their excellence and skill. Help us purchase trophies and medals to present to winning teams throughout the weekend, giving students an opportunity to go for the gold and achieve so much more than they could've possibly imagined.
-Promotional Materials. The publicity team at Lara Media wants to spread the word about the Memorial Cup all around Oregon and to do that we need to design and purchase flyers, posters and other promotional materials.
-Water for teams and volunteers.
 Other Ways You Can Help:
Donations of the following would be greatly appreciated: Flats of bottled water, soccer balls, food for volunteers, prizes for the children, or your time! Those interested in volunteering should send a message to contact@laramedia.com.

story:
Help Me "Squat" My House, Snatched by Intentional Community

What happens when a nonprofit corporation decides it wants to change its mission but poverty-level old people have built homes on the corporation's land, in accordance with its original mission? The corporation evicts the old people — without compensating them for their houses.

And totally gets away with it!

This is what happened to me and my ex-husband Rick, a wrong done to us by an intentional community in Tennessee run by a nonprofit called Rocinante. I lived there and Rick built a house there, and he gave me half-ownership of the house. Rocinante took the house and refused to reimburse Rick or me.

Simultaneously Help Un-Yoke Me from the Friend I've Been Divorced from for 25 Years

Due to the poverty caused by Rick being deprived of the house he built, Rick and I have since been yoked together. We are friends, but we have been divorced for 25 years. Both of us have had to live on my social security disability income for two years now, and we both need our independent lives back, and a relief from dire poverty.

Rick has been experiencing TIAs (ministrokes) from hypertension and is not able to work. I am on disability for multiple sclerosis. We are currently living in Mexico in an attempt to be able to afford to exist.

I Need to Get to Tennessee to Claim My House

The intentional community is counting on our poverty to keep us from getting our house back. The fact that we are not on site, in Tennessee, could allow our rights to expire, and allows our plight to be completely ignored. Rick is too sick to undertake this project right now, but I need to be there, on site, in the house, in their face, in the media, insisting on justice.

I say, Either let us live in our house, or pay us for it! It's not okay to just steal it.

While Rocinante is no longer the community that Rick and I signed up for — considering the nonprofit dissolved the community, and has treated us disgracefully —Rick built the house, it is paid for, and we need a place we can afford to live.

Alternatively, the house is easily worth $25,000, and those who took the house should pay us for it.

What I'm Proposing to Do

After two years of trying to talk to the nonprofit and getting no response, I am ready to go "squat" in Rick's and my house until justice is done — in the middle of the nonprofit's antagonism, in spite of those who say I can't, in the winter, in the middle of the woods, and next door to the nonprofit's property manager — a Brazilian street-fighting champion.

While I'm there, I intend to also get justice for my other, elderly neighbor, who was evicted by that street-fighting champ last Christmas Eve.

I intend to be a constant reminder to the wrongdoers, telling the truth and demanding justice. I intend to visit senators and representatives and county officials. I intend to involve media in a big and ongoing way. Some of you will be seeing me on TV, and you will be reading about me on the internet. If you read the detailed story (www.fukushimafaq.info/rocinante), you'll see that some rather famous counterculture heroes are at the heart of this house-grabbing. You will see there is quite an amazing story here.

I intend to achieve: 1) Secure the rights to Rick's and my house so we can live there, rent it out, or sell it; or 2) Be compensated $25,000 for it — and my evicted elderly neighbor gets compensated $10,000 for the house he built.

What I Need

All my current income (social security disability) is used to support Rick's and my Mexico household. My savings are gone.

I need money to travel from Mexico to Tennessee. I can take a bus for about $450 (36 hours, with a cheap motel somewhere en route). (Flying would cost around $700 by the time shuttles on both ends are figured in, so I intend to take the bus.) I would like to leave in early January, or as soon as I can.

I need money to get moved into the house, and a reserve for backup lodging should I not immediately be able to get into the house. I will need to get the electricity turned on in the house, which will require a deposit. I may need to buy a heater and a couch  or bed to sleep on. I may need a locksmith. My water pipes may be frozen.

I need money to exist (eat, for instance) while I work hard every day to raise awareness of the situation and achieve a fast, fair solution.

I do not have a laptop, but I will need phone and internet access, in the middle of the woods. An inexpensive smartphone should be able to keep me in touch with the media and provide internet/email access.

I no longer have a car and will need to sometimes pay local people to drive me places. Ideally, I could afford to rent someone's extra clunker. I will need to buy a coat at Goodwill.

I figure $1950 will get me there, get me set up (including utility deposit and phone), pay indiegogo commission, and meet barebones necessary expenses to keep me alive and productive for two months, with a small reserve. By the end of that time, I intend that the house will have been restored to me and Rick, or we will have been reimbursed for the house.

In a non-monetary vein, it might be helpful to have a couple of additional hardy, high-quality squatters with me to swell the ranks.

A Call for Justice

As you can see from the detailed story (www.fukushimafaq.info/rocinante), I spent many years doing volunteer work for the very people — my fellow members on the board of directors! — who then turned around and took Rick's and my house away. These people were supposed to be highly spiritually evolved, but when it came right down to it, their countercultural, nonprofit corporation was just as greedy and amoral, and their functioning just as self-serving, as any corporation anywhere.

I don't want them to get away with it. I want justice.

Anything you can do to help — and to help get the word out — will work to affirm rightness in the world. Please read the detailed story at www.fukushimafaq.info/rocinante. Old people should not be evicted from the homes they built for themselves — and without a penny of compensation!

story:
What This Is All About

Hello everyone!  My name is Heather Riney and I made a decision to leave my corporate job (finance & operations) a little over a year ago.  Like many, I wanted to find a deeper purpose to what I was doing with my life, not merely follow the path that just happened to be laid out in front of me.  I want to be excited & passionate about what I do every day...direct my gifts and talents towards the things that truly matter to me & inspire others to do the same.  I've spent much of the past year traveling to third world countries...learning, volunteering & meeting some incredible people.  From my experiences both abroad and right here within the amazing community that is Nashville, the idea for this business slowly but surely came into focus.  

Atmalogy is a word I essentially made up that captures the essence of the business to serve as a constant reminder of it's purpose.  'Atma,' a Hindu word, loosely means 'one's true self' and 'ology' is 'the study of.'  Atmalogy will be a unique community meeting space...a place where people can come together in a shared space to learn & share & grow.  In this age of abundant technology (while incredibly valuable!), nothing can replace the energy that is created from face to face connection with others. 

Located on West End near Vanderbilt, the space will have 8 rooms of varying sizes to accomodate 2 to 75+ people for a variety of needs...client meetings, brainstorming sessions, book clubs, workshops, yoga classes, song-writing collaboration...the possibilities are endless.  It's the perfect setting for individuals and businesses alike to work (& play!) in a setting that is flexible, casual & creative.  There is no monthly commitment and there will even be a way to book the space online.  Prices will start as low as $10 per hour, and discounted packages can lower the rates up to 50%!!!  The space is also being designed in such a way that components such as lighting, acoustics, color scheme, ergonomics & more will be considered to create a space that supports and encourages comfort, productivity, creativity & overall well-being. Several images in the video are renderings created to show examples of the environment being created (also see on Gallery tab).

At the "heart" of this space will be an on-site cafe.  Open to those renting the space as well as those who aren't, it will serve a selection of mostly local, organic, healthy & really delicious food and beverage options, many of which have been inspired by the items sampled in the various cafes I discovered during my travels.  Check out the sample menu on the gallery tab.  Catering options for those renting the spaces will also be available.  

Creating this space is incredibly important to me, and I'm excited about the opportunity to bring it to the Nashville community.  It's the space I have wished existed during these past several months for my own reasons & everyone I have spoken with has had their own ideas on how they will use it!  Like many of you these days, I find myself working at home or out of cafes.  At home, I'm easily distracted or find myself feeling lost in the seemingly endless, lonely depths of my computer.  Cafes are often noisy - definitely not the setting for a private meeting or call.  This space will combine the networking benefit & convenience of a cafe with the privacy & functionality of a private meeting space.  It will be an accessible resource for the whole community to use as a place to connect & create in a neutral, comfortable & casual (yet still professional) space. 

And because I want this to be a space truly shaped and inspired by the community it will serve, I've decided to use this format to raise the funds necessary to make it a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

In addition to my personal investment and the investment from a few individual investors with a complimentary background & mutual passion for the concept, these funds are needed to fully cover the build-out of the space, set-up of a cafe & furnishing of the various meeting rooms.  

Your contributions will translate into dollars to be used toward renting these amazing spaces once our doors are open, items in our cafe, and opportunities to explore some of the types of things that could be happening at any time in the space!  And of course you will be ensuring that an amazing addition to Nashville's community will now be here whenever you need it!!!

Even if you don't live in Nashville currently, your support would be greatly appreciated...maybe one day we can bring an atmalogy to your city too!!!  

The Impact

As I mentioned before, there is nothing that replaces the energy & inspiration created by connecting with like-minded people.  There isn't one path to happiness...we each are unique, we each have our own passions, and we each have different things to contribute.  But we are each other's mirrors.  And this space, like none that currently exist, will help to create an environment that allows for meaningful, authentic & exciting connections, so please HELP ME BRING IT TO LIFE!

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute doesn't mean you can't help!  Spread the word and share this campaign with everyone you know!  Facebook, twitter, you guys know how it works.  :)

Questions?  E-mail me: info@atmalogy.com

story:
One of the best parts about making giant puppets for justice is figuring out what to do with them after the political demonstrations are over and you realize you and your friends have made a puppet that is way too big. Thank godness I ran into Judea at Wangari Gardens in DC, and was silly enough to share with her my idea of using the 81' sunflower dragon puppet you see here as the spine of a greenhouse for this pretty large garden...

After all, she liked the idea, and told me to talk to Josh, who would soon talk me down to a more feasible first step towards future marvels. A wind-break for recently planted medicinal trees is a much less silly idea, indeed – especially with winter/apocalypse coming and whatnot. :o)

But seriously folks, in the spirit of living the change I want to see in the world, I see this project as a powerful way to attract more creative community energy to an already inspiring project . The more we can engage the work of building food sovereignty and community health with a joyful, adventurous spirit, the better off we are going to be. This is what my art and activism is all about - So I thank you for your support! 

Here's whats needed:

Weatherproofing – lightly repairing and recoating all of the head surfaces with paper mache, plus covering all of the bamboo support system and the repaired head with several coats of environmentally friendly shellac.

Installation – attaching an additional layer of agricultural netting below the dragon's body and mounting the whole structure securely to the ground.

Sustainability – This is my first of a prayerful many permaculture + art projects, so I will do as much as I can to not only maintain the sculpture as long as possible, but to cultivate more community art projects related to this community's guardin' dragon for years to come. I have a long history of facilitating community art for justice on mama earth, and thoughts about this dragon incubating community creativity have gotten me out of bed in the morning when little else would.

 

Thank you for your generous support – the $1314 goal is a humble estimate of the time and resources I will likely end up putting into this work and so any amount over the top will be put to good use.

 

If you just can't afford to support financially, thats awesome, too. Sharing links and feeling the love are important pieces of the puzzles. May we all find what we need. Blessings and thanks again!

 

For more images from the dragon's history:

http://www.soaw.org/component/content/article/252-april-2012/3895-we-wont-stop-until-they-do

http://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.101506...

story: Trying to move back to New England and build something there ASAP. I will pay everyone back in one way or another who contributes. While I could get a part time gig and do it the old fashioned way, I have been reluctant to do so because I want to leave so soon I don't want to burn anyone. Quite the Catch-22!
story_txt: Trying to move back to New England and build something there ASAP. I will pay everyone back in one way or another who contributes. While I could get a part time gig and do it the old fashioned way, I have been reluctant to do so because I want to leave so soon I don't want to burn anyone. Quite the Catch-22!

story:
Life In Cusco

We realised our dream to come to  Peru and in particular Cusco earlier this year and we feel extremely fortunate for that.  We believe that life is a big adventure and that you should try to spend every day of your life doing what you enjoy.

Now that we have been here for three months and have experienced life in Peru, we would like to move onto our next dream - managing our own hostel or small hotel.

Life has thrown us a number of curve-balls over the last few years and government organisations and immigration departments have not helped our cause.  But we are motivated to improve our life ten-fold so that we are able to return to our country of choice and richer in all sense of the word.

About Us

Before I go any further, let me introduce you to the "we".

I am Michelle (originally from Australia), wife to Matt and mum to Emilia and Matthew.  I work part time as a ghost writer and manager of social media accounts for busy entrepreneurs.  I also write and publish e-books on Amazon for others.  For more information visit www.michelletupy.com. 

Matt (originally from Canada) is a busy man, always working to try to give us a better life.  Currently he is teaching English in Peru although his background is in hotel management, hence our desire to run our own business.

Emilia is 8 and loves to sing, dance and eat bacon!  Emilia thinks that running her own hostel would be awesome so her friends and cousins get to stay with us when they come to visit.  Her big dream is to be famous - so watch this space!

Matthew is 3 and loves reading books and watching Mickey Mouse.  He says that his favourite food is noodles and he is constantly imagining that he is on a bus, train or plane going to some destination or other.

Dream Large

By helping us realise our next goal, it would enable us to reach out and help others in the local community who need it whether it means offering them accommodation, work or both.  We are all for helping others and have been giving on "Kiva" for a number of years having amassed over 30 loans. But even we recognise we can do "more".

Managing a hostel would allow us to be able to support our family without worrying how we are going to pay bills or feed our family.  The money will help us secure our own business and ultimately we would be able to return to the country of our choice without any money worries or immigration issues that have plagued us in the past.

(view of one of the hostel rooms)

What We Need

We have found the hostel of our dreams however they require a deposit of $20,000 on top of the monthly rent.

The hostel is a 3 star, 12 room property based near to the San Blas area in Cusco and is fully furnished and functioning, hence the large deposit they require.

Without a deposit of this size, the only hostel we could get is one which we would not be happy to represent.  We want it to be liveable for both ourselves and our guests otherwise what is the point!

It is lovely - it really is. Just what you would expect a Peruvian hostel to look like.  And once we have secured the lease, we will be happy to share all the details with you.

The hostel requires only minimal work in terms of adding some radiators to the rooms therefore will not be as big a money pit as other properties we have seen.  

“Happiness is not something ready made. It comes from your own actions.” 

― Dalai Lama XIV

(view of one of the hostel rooms)

Spread The Word

We totally understand what it is like to have no money or not be able to help someone out, but if you can't help in monetary terms, we would certainly appreciate if you could spread the word.
story_txt:
Life In Cusco
We realised our dream to come to  Peru and in particular Cusco earlier this year and we feel extremely fortunate for that.  We believe that life is a big adventure and that you should try to spend every day of your life doing what you enjoy.
Now that we have been here for three months and have experienced life in Peru, we would like to move onto our next dream - managing our own hostel or small hotel.
Life has thrown us a number of curve-balls over the last few years and government organisations and immigration departments have not helped our cause.  But we are motivated to improve our life ten-fold so that we are able to return to our country of choice and richer in all sense of the word.

About UsBefore I go any further, let me introduce you to the "we".
I am Michelle (originally from Australia), wife to Matt and mum to Emilia and Matthew.  I work part time as a ghost writer and manager of social media accounts for busy entrepreneurs.  I also write and publish e-books on Amazon for others.  For more information visit www.michelletupy.com. 
Matt (originally from Canada) is a busy man, always working to try to give us a better life.  Currently he is teaching English in Peru although his background is in hotel management, hence our desire to run our own business.
Emilia is 8 and loves to sing, dance and eat bacon!  Emilia thinks that running her own hostel would be awesome so her friends and cousins get to stay with us when they come to visit.  Her big dream is to be famous - so watch this space!

Spread The Word
We totally understand what it is like to have no money or not be able to help someone out, but if you can't help in monetary terms, we would certainly appreciate if you could spread the word.

story:
Jayden “Jay Jay” Oulahyane was a sweet and beautiful boy who spend his short life dealing with repeated daily seizures, breathing problems, feeing issues, kidney disease, multiple hospitalizations, therapies, and doctors’ appointments. But these things did not define him. Jay received and gave more love in six years, seven months, and thirteen days than most people do in a lifetime. He had a contagious smile that came from deep in his soul and loved snuggling more than anything!

Jayden taught everyone who met him about unconditional love and acceptance. In the spirit of this love and in memory of Jay Jay, we’d like to start a foundation centered around the idea of paying it forward, or as we like to refer to it, “Jay It Forward”. While we haven’t decided on all of the details, we’d like the foundation to help children who are medically fragile and their families. Whether it may be a bill, medical equipment, services, or even food, the foundation would focus its time and energy to help these amazing children and their courageous caretakers.

The money raised will go toward costs, supplies, and initial funds to get the foundation up and running. We are very excited to move forward with this project and even more thrilled to help people in need. Please join our movement and help us to “Jay It Forward”!

Thank you so much,

Kari Oulahyane, Jay Jay’s Proud Mother

Matt Hall, Jay Jay’s Proud Uncle

 

Visit us on Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/JayItForward

 

Contact Matt with any questions: dmatthew.hall@gmail.com

And please get the word out about www.indiegogo.com , it's amazing!

story:
Oklahoma Strong

The Oklahoma Tornadoes have created widespread destruction and injured and killed many. Communities and individuals will need specific and direct help. Many people will create fundraising campaigns to get that help, but many of those campaigns are not legitimate.
 
The Wish Upon A Hero Foundation can help those families in need while ensuring that their needs are real through an application process which requires background checks. The Foundation has helped grant over 100,000 wishes for families across the country including hundreds of people from the Hurricane Sandy disaster.

Be A Hero

The American Red Cross specializes in disaster relief. It helps get the tornado victims into a safe environment and helps them with basic necessities for an initial period of time. After that, those families will be on their own and will need real help. That's where Wish Upon A Hero comes in. It can help with long term recovery and unmet needs such as funeral expenses, home repairs, and medical expenses. Wish Upon A Hero is looking to raise a minimum of $100,000 to help those families for the recovery phase.
 
Wish Upon A Hero Foundation is a 501c3 charity. Your donation is tax deductible.

How You Can Help

Every donation is an important one, even if it is only $5. If you can't donate at this time, be a supporter and share this campaign.
 
 
 

DONATE BY PHONE
Text HERO to 80088 to make a $5 donation.

$5.00 donation to Wish Upon A Hero. Charges will appear on your wireless bill, or be deducted from your prepaid balance. All purchases must be authorized by account holder. Must be 18 years of age or have parental permission to participate. Message and Data Rates May Apply. Text STOP to 80088 to STOP. Text HELP to 80088 for HELP.  Full Terms: mGive.org/T. Privacy Policy.

story:
Short Summary

I’m a free-spirit, passionate, coffee-drinking, craft-making, foodie, budding entrepreneur. I am currently at Algonquin College learning all the tricks of the trade on how to open up my own business. I believe in doing what I love, and making a living bringing what I love to those around me. That’s where Ottawa’s Wheelys Cafe comes through. This cart will the beginning of my long awaited journey to own my own business. For many years I have dreamt of opening a café where I can be my own boss, make people smile, and serve yummy food. The fact that the funding is going to be helped by those around me is such a humbling and encouraging thought. It makes me want to make this a success even that much more, because you believe in me.

What We Need

This is the beginning of a big dream I’ve had for a long time. So, any contributions will mean so much to me, because it will mean I’m getting close to that goal. Ottawa’s Wheelys Café is aiming to raise $4,600 in 35 days! These will help cover all the following start-up costs:

·  The Wheelys Cart itself!

·  Mobile Refreshment Cart permit

·  Insurance

·  Finding the best local, fair-trade, organic coffee to serve

·  Purchasing biodegradable coffee ware

·  Storage Unit to tuck it in at night

What You Get

Your contribution will go directly towards supporting an up-and-coming local eco-friendly business, which is already exciting!

On top of that, there are a range of perks that come along with helping me out. Each and every contributor will be personally thanked by me.. isn’t that all you need?? No, there’s more to it than that. The perks range from free coffee cards, personal coffee deliveries, Ottawa’s Wheelys Café merch, free catering, and more!

The Impact

Biking around the city serving yummy coffee and treats to the city of Ottawa. Doesn’t that just already put a smile on your face?

Other Ways You Can Help

Ottawa’s Wheelys Café encourages and is grateful for any contribution! Please feel free to share this post, get the word out there, and contact me with any questions or comments. I love connecting with those are who share love and passion for life.

story:
[scroll down for english version]

Hola. Soy marifer. Me dirijo a ustedes porque quisiera pedir su ayuda. Como mujer trans, migrante indocumentada racializada y repatriada que ha batallado con la pobreza y la violencia a lo largo de su vida, no es algo sencillo sobrevivir (escribo más sobre mi realidad abajo). Pero ante toda esa violencia, tengo una propuesta. Para poder tener una situación más estable, planeo abrir un restaurante pequeño. He trabajado mucho en restaurantes, y vengo de una familia que se ha dedicado a trabajar en restaurantes por mucho tiempo. El plan al de mi familia al emigrar a estados unidos era abrir un restaurante—plan que fracasó por la enfermedad de mi papá y el desencanto del sueño americano. Pero me dejó con muchas ideas para abrir uno (abajo explico más sobre ello). Pero para hacerlo, necesito fondos y apoyo, y así es como pueden ayudar.


He hecho los cálculos, y para poder conseguir los materiales necesarios, rentar el lugar, y tener suficiente para sostenerlo durante los primeros 3 (aprox) meses mientras se estabiliza un poco, necesitaré 10,000 dólares (usd). Aprecio mucho su apoyo, y si como yo tampoco están en una buena situación económica, también pueden apoyar compartiendo, ayudándome a promover el lugar una vez que se establezca, o yendo a echarse un taco cuando abramos. También este  tipo de ayuda será sumamente apreciada y agradecida. Si me pueden ayudar con una aportación monetaria o con compartir esta página con amistades, me servirá mucho. Además, para agradecerles, para las personas que viven cerca, podrán comer algo gratis en el restaurante, y a las personas que viven lejos, les mandaré una carta hecha a mano (si lo desean) como agradecimiento. Asi que, si comparten la pagina, mandenme una captura de pantalla para que puedan obtener su platillo gratis o les haga su carta! :) [carita feliz]


El restaurante será un restaurante pequeño en una ubicación céntrica del d.f.. Ofreceremos comida tex-mex, opciones vegetarianas y más. Creo que la comida tex-mex es una buena opción porque es sencilla y ligera para el paladar, para quienes la conocen y quienes no, además de que habemos muchas personas que nos repatriamos de estados unidos y extrañamos al menos un poco esta comida. Usaremos las redes sociales para ayudar en la difusión del lugar; para que la gente pueda enterarse del lugar, y además, los lugares con opciones vegetarianas y veganas generan mucha atención en las redes sociales por ser un mercado específico. Los precios serán accesibles (algo poco común para restaurantes que tienen un énfasis en comida vegetariana y vegana), lo que hará el lugar más rentable. Yo y mi hermano (quien me ayudará a establecer el restaurante) tenemos experiencia trabajando en distintas áreas de restaurantes, así que no solamente sabemos cómo hacer uno que tenga éxito, pero tenemos las habilidades para trabajarlo.


Les cuento un poco más sobre mí: emigré a estados unidos en la infancia y regresé a mi pueblo a los 18, y tuve que emigrar de nuevo, ahora al d.f. por no encontrar trabajo ahí. En el tiempo que llevo en la ciudad, he tenido dificultad hasta para encontrar trabajos mal-pagados y muy explotadores. Por encima de todo, cuando sí he logrado obtener trabajo, he tenido que usar mi nombre legal, y no tengo la posibilidad de presentarme como quisiera. Este restaurante me permitirá no solamente sobrevivir, pero también tener estabilidad laboral, y no tendré que lidiar tanto con cuestiones de transfobia por cuestiones de poder laboral.


No soy una recién egresada de la universidad que está pasando por un momento difícil para encontrar trabajo, sino una persona que en 30 años--como muchxs de mi comunidad que compartimos clase, y de la comunidad trans con quienes comparto otra lucha--probablemente estaré en situaciones económicas difíciles, y este proyecto puede darme estabilidad y cambiar mi situación a largo plazo, no es meramente algo para hacer algo “chido” en lo que encuentro otro  trabajo—además, óptimamente, el proyecto buscará hacer cosas por mi comunidad—desde mi  familia que también está en pobreza (si se expandiera, idealmente sería con ellxs), hasta personas que podríamos emplear en el futuro—e intentará aliarse con proyectos no lucrativos que busquen ayudar a personas  en situación de pobreza, trans, queer, etc—o sea que el  proyecto en  general buscará a largo plazo ayudar a personas que  viven estas  violencias. Sé  que el proyecto no puede poner un fin a la violencia clasista, y en última instancia, el fin que debemos buscar es abolir las estructuras que violentan a tantas personas en base de clase, raza, género, discapacidad, etc. pero por ahora, este proyecto sería una forma  para mí y lxs otrxs que puedan beneficiarse de él, de resistir toda la violencia del capitalismo, y construirse más como un proyecto mutualista.


Estoy agradecida de tener una  comunidad de apoyo tan grande y espero que eso sea algo que me pueda ayudar a salir de esta situación. Su apoyo me permitirá enfocarme en algo que me pueda sostener más al largo plazo, y también me permitirá seguir escribiendo sobre asuntos  trans, migratorios, raciales, descoloniales, de la violencias y exclusión como parte de las cárceles y de las universidades, etc., y me permitirá seguir con mis planes personales: planes en la  música y el arte, poesía, etc., e intentar hacer cosas por mis comunidades. Tener un ingreso estable me dará la oportunidad de no estarme preocupando siempre por mi pobreza, y ayudaría a sostener e impulsar todos lo demás en mi vida.


Si quieren ayudar pero no por este medio, mándenme un correo a fer.chavez.42@gmail.com


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Hello. My name is marifer. i’m writing this because I need your help. As a trans undocumented immigrant woman who was taken to the u.s. as a child and has since returned to mexico, and has battled with poverty and violence throughout her life, it is not easy to survive (i will talk more of my reality later). But in light of all this violence, i have an idea to solve it. To make my economic situation more stable, i plan on opening a small restaurant. i have worked in multiple restaurants, and my whole family has worked at restaurants for a long time. In fact, the reason my family went to the u.s. in the first place is that my parents wanted to save some money to open a restaurant in our hometown—this plan failed due to my father’s illness and the disenchantment of my siblings and i in the american dream. But the whole ordeal left me with many ideas to open a restaurant (I will explain in detail later). But to do this, I need money and support, and this is how you can help.


i have calculated the expenses, and to get the necessary materials, rent a place, and have enough money to sustain the restaurant the first 3 months or so, while it becomes stable, i will need about 10,000 dollars. i appreciate your support, and if like me, you’re not in a good economic situation, you can also help by sharing this, helping us promote the place when we start, or going to grab a bite when we’re settled in. This type of help will also be appreciated and thanked. If you can help by donating or by sharing this petition, it will help me a lot. And to thank you, for those who live close by or plan on visiting the area, you can eat something free from the restaurant, and those who are unable to visit the place, i will send you (if you wish) a handwritten letter thanking you. So, if you share the petition, send me a screenshot so that you can get your free menu item or your letter!  :) [smiley face]


The restaurant will be small and located in a central location in Mexico City. will will offer tex-mex food, with vegetarian options and more. i think tex-mex is a good option because it's simple and easy on taste buds, for those who are familiar with it and those who aren't, plus there's lots of us who have returned to mexico from the u.s. and miss this food at least a little bit. we will use social networks to help with the restaurant's  promotion, so that people can find out about it, and besides that, places with vegetarian and vegan options get a lot of attention online since they have a specific market. The prices will be accessible (which is pretty unusual for restaurants with an emphasis on vegetarian and vegan food) which will make it do even better. my brother (who will help me start-up  the restaurant) and i have experience working in a variety of positions in restaurants, so on top of knowing how to make a successful one, we have the abilities to work there.


Now let me tell you a bit about me: i immigrated to the u.s. when i was a child, and i returned to my hometown at 18. Then I had to emigrate again, this time to mexico city because there were no jobs where i’m from. In the time that i’ve been living in this city, i’ve even had difficulty finding poorly paid and very exploitative jobs. On top of it all, when i have been able to find work, i’ve had to use my legal name, and i don’t have the option of presenting as i would like to. This restaurant will let me do much more than survive; i’ll be able to have a stable job, and i won’t have to deal as much with questions of transphobia based on job subordination.


i’m not someone who’s recently graduated from a university and is just currently having a difficult time finding a job. Instead, i’m someone who in 30 years -- like many from my community who i share an economic class with, and those in the trans community who I share a struggle with -- will probably be in a difficult economic situation still, and this project can give me stability and also help to change my situation in the long term; it’s not about finding something “cool” to do while I look for another job or something better -- additionally, optimally,  the project intends to do things for my community--starting with my family who is also in poverty (if it expands, it would ideally be with them)--to people we could employ in the future--and we will work on becoming allies with non-profit projects that focus on helping trans, queer, etc. people and/or those in a situation of poverty; in other words, the project intends to help others that live with these violences in the long term. i know that the project can’t get rid of class violence, and overall, the goal we need to fight for is to abolish the structures that hurt so many based on class, race, gender, ability, etc., but for now, this project would be a way for me, as well as others who can benefit from it, to resist some of the violence of capitalism, and to construct more of a mutualist project.

i am so thankful for having a large support community and i hope that this is something that will help me get out of this situation. Your support will allow me to focus on something that will help me long term, and will allow me to keep on writing about trans, migrant, racial and colonial issues, about the violence and exclusion of prisons and universities, etc., and will allow me to pursue my personal goals in music, art and poetry, and to try to do more for my communities. Having a stable source of income will allow me to stop worrying about my poverty all the time, and will help sustain all other aspects of my life.


If you wanna help but not through here, send me a message to fer.chavez.42@gmail.com

Creo que la comida tex-mex es una buena opción porque es sencilla y ligera para el paladar, para quienes la conocen y quienes no, además de que habemos muchas personas que nos repatriamos de estados unidos y extrañamos al menos un poco esta comida. Usaremos las redes sociales para ayudar en la difusión del lugar; para que la gente pueda enterarse del lugar, y además, los lugares con opciones vegetarianas y veganas generan mucha atención en las redes sociales por ser un mercado específico. Los precios serán accesibles (algo poco común para restaurantes que tienen un énfasis en comida vegetariana y vegana), lo que hará el lugar más rentable. Yo y mi hermano (quien me ayudará a establecer el restaurante) tenemos experiencia trabajando en distintas áreas de restaurantes, así que no solamente sabemos cómo hacer uno que tenga éxito, pero tenemos las habilidades para trabajarlo.Les cuento un poco más sobre mí: emigré a estados unidos en la infancia y regresé a mi pueblo a los 18, y tuve que emigrar de nuevo, ahora al d.f. por no encontrar trabajo ahí. En el tiempo que llevo en la ciudad, he tenido dificultad hasta para encontrar trabajos mal-pagados y muy explotadores. Por encima de todo, cuando sí he logrado obtener trabajo, he tenido que usar mi nombre legal, y no tengo la posibilidad de presentarme como quisiera. Este restaurante me permitirá no solamente sobrevivir, pero también tener estabilidad laboral, y no tendré que lidiar tanto con cuestiones de transfobia por cuestiones de poder laboral.No soy una recién egresada de la universidad que está pasando por un momento difícil para encontrar trabajo, sino una persona que en 30 años--como muchxs de mi comunidad que compartimos clase, y de la comunidad trans con quienes comparto otra lucha--probablemente estaré en situaciones económicas difíciles, y este proyecto puede darme estabilidad y cambiar mi situación a largo plazo, no es meramente algo para hacer algo “chido” en lo que encuentro otro  trabajo—además, óptimamente, el proyecto buscará hacer cosas por mi comunidad—desde mi  familia que también está en pobreza (si se expandiera, idealmente sería con ellxs), hasta personas que podríamos emplear en el futuro—e intentará aliarse con proyectos no lucrativos que busquen ayudar a personas  en situación de pobreza, trans, queer, etc—o sea que el  proyecto en  general buscará a largo plazo ayudar a personas que  viven estas  violencias. Sé  que el proyecto no puede poner un fin a la violencia clasista, y en última instancia, el fin que debemos buscar es abolir las estructuras que violentan a tantas personas en base de clase, raza, género, discapacidad, etc. pero por ahora, este proyecto sería una forma  para mí y lxs otrxs que puedan beneficiarse de él, de resistir toda la violencia del capitalismo, y construirse más como un proyecto mutualista.Estoy agradecida de tener una  comunidad de apoyo tan grande y espero que eso sea algo que me pueda ayudar a salir de esta situación. Su apoyo me permitirá enfocarme en algo que me pueda sostener más al largo plazo, y también me permitirá seguir escribiendo sobre asuntos  trans, migratorios, raciales, descoloniales, de la violencias y exclusión como parte de las cárceles y de las universidades, etc., y me permitirá seguir con mis planes personales: planes en la  música y el arte, poesía, etc., e intentar hacer cosas por mis comunidades. Tener un ingreso estable me dará la oportunidad de no estarme preocupando siempre por mi pobreza, y ayudaría a sostener e impulsar todos lo demás en mi vida.Si quieren ayudar pero no por este medio, mándenme un correo a fer.chavez.42@gmail.com----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Hello. My name is marifer. i’m writing this because I need your help. As a trans undocumented immigrant woman who was taken to the u.s. as a child and has since returned to mexico, and has battled with poverty and violence throughout her life, it is not easy to survive (i will talk more of my reality later). But in light of all this violence, i have an idea to solve it. To make my economic situation more stable, i plan on opening a small restaurant. i have worked in multiple restaurants, and my whole family has worked at restaurants for a long time. In fact, the reason my family went to the u.s. in the first place is that my parents wanted to save some money to open a restaurant in our hometown—this plan failed due to my father’s illness and the disenchantment of my siblings and i in the american dream. But the whole ordeal left me with many ideas to open a restaurant (I will explain in detail later). But to do this, I need money and support, and this is how you can help.i have calculated the expenses, and to get the necessary materials, rent a place, and have enough money to sustain the restaurant the first 3 months or so, while it becomes stable, i will need about 10,000 dollars. i appreciate your support, and if like me, you’re not in a good economic situation, you can also help by sharing this, helping us promote the place when we start, or going to grab a bite when we’re settled in. This type of help will also be appreciated and thanked. If you can help by donating or by sharing this petition, it will help me a lot. And to thank you, for those who live close by or plan on visiting the area, you can eat something free from the restaurant, and those who are unable to visit the place, i will send you (if you wish) a handwritten letter thanking you. So, if you share the petition, send me a screenshot so that you can get your free menu item or your letter!  :) [smiley face]The restaurant will be small and located in a central location in Mexico City. will will offer tex-mex food, with vegetarian options and more. i think tex-mex is a good option because it's simple and easy on taste buds, for those who are familiar with it and those who aren't, plus there's lots of us who have returned to mexico from the u.s. and miss this food at least a little bit. we will use social networks to help with the restaurant's  promotion, so that people can find out about it, and besides that, places with vegetarian and vegan options get a lot of attention online since they have a specific market. The prices will be accessible (which is pretty unusual for restaurants with an emphasis on vegetarian and vegan food) which will make it do even better. my brother (who will help me start-up  the restaurant) and i have experience working in a variety of positions in restaurants, so on top of knowing how to make a successful one, we have the abilities to work there.Now let me tell you a bit about me: i immigrated to the u.s. when i was a child, and i returned to my hometown at 18. Then I had to emigrate again, this time to mexico city because there were no jobs where i’m from. In the time that i’ve been living in this city, i’ve even had difficulty finding poorly paid and very exploitative jobs. On top of it all, when i have been able to find work, i’ve had to use my legal name, and i don’t have the option of presenting as i would like to. This restaurant will let me do much more than survive; i’ll be able to have a stable job, and i won’t have to deal as much with questions of transphobia based on job subordination.i’m not someone who’s recently graduated from a university and is just currently having a difficult time finding a job. Instead, i’m someone who in 30 years -- like many from my community who i share an economic class with, and those in the trans community who I share a struggle with -- will probably be in a difficult economic situation still, and this project can give me stability and also help to change my situation in the long term; it’s not about finding something “cool” to do while I look for another job or something better -- additionally, optimally,  the project intends to do things for my community--starting with my family who is also in poverty (if it expands, it would ideally be with them)--to people we could employ in the future--and we will work on becoming allies with non-profit projects that focus on helping trans, queer, etc. people and/or those in a situation of poverty; in other words, the project intends to help others that live with these violences in the long term. i know that the project can’t get rid of class violence, and overall, the goal we need to fight for is to abolish the structures that hurt so many based on class, race, gender, ability, etc., but for now, this project would be a way for me, as well as others who can benefit from it, to resist some of the violence of capitalism, and to construct more of a mutualist project.i am so thankful for having a large support community and i hope that this is something that will help me get out of this situation. Your support will allow me to focus on something that will help me long term, and will allow me to keep on writing about trans, migrant, racial and colonial issues, about the violence and exclusion of prisons and universities, etc., and will allow me to pursue my personal goals in music, art and poetry, and to try to do more for my communities. Having a stable source of income will allow me to stop worrying about my poverty all the time, and will help sustain all other aspects of my life.If you wanna help but not through here, send me a message to fer.chavez.42@gmail.com

story:
Who we are

Since 2009 SIP! events has been successfully curating casual, entertaining, and informative wine parties in homes and offices across Southern California.  Now, we’re ready to package our unique approach to wine education and events in, well, a box.  SIP! in a BOX will offer wine enthusiasts across the country the opportunity to purchase our best-selling wine flights from our online wine shop.


More than 4 years of successful wine events

Our clients count on us to offer something special for their guests who want to learn about wine in a fun, approachable way. Over the past 4 years SIP! has hosted all kinds of wine events from corporate office mixers to lively bachelorette weekends to up-scale celebrity dinner parties.  We allow our clients to enjoy the event by handling all of the details.  We select and research the wines according to the party’s theme and our wine expert brings everything needed to serve and pour the wines for the party.  

  


Our style sets us apart: we’re not stuffy about wine.  People feel comfortable asking questions and trying new varietals.  Often the wine becomes the entertainment for the evening.

Currently, no online wine retailers are able to offer what we can.  Our trained SIP! wine experts choosing amazing wines, preparing educational materials, and packaging all of the intricacies needed for a wine tasting party.  Four years and a myriad of wine events have prepared us for breaking into this niche market.

What’s in the box?

1. 5 different bottles of delicious wine

2. Tasting note cards for each guest

3. SIP wine opener

4. E-SOMM DVD

A little more detail...

1. For each SIP! in a BOX, our wine experts select five bottles of wine that are not only delicious, but work well together when tasted in a progressive flight.  Moreover, the wines in each box will be selected to suit a unique theme.  The options are endless, but some examples of themes would be: all Pinot Noirs from different regions showing off how this sexy grape can range in flavors…or all California Chardonnays…or a What is a Bordeaux Blend? flight, etc.  

2. In addition to the wine, customers receive everything they need to throw their own SIP! event including tasting note cards which guests can use to take notes on the wines they are tasting.

3. We will include a high quality SIP wine opener so you can open your wines in style.

4. Clients tell us over and over that our casual presentation and approachability set our events apart from others.  So, how do we include this style in a SIP! in a BOX?  We’re really excited to offer something else that is not being done.  Inside each SIP! in a  BOX is a video that hosts can play on their TV or laptop during the tasting event.  Wine experts will walk the group through the flight, offer information on the wines and spark great wine conversations for the group. We call it an E-SOMM.  Guests will feel like their very own sommelier is walking them through the flight while sitting in their living room with friends or mingling with coworkers at the office.

  

What We Need

Like most start-up companies, in order to expand we need funds to build our growing infrastructure.  We’ve already laid the groundwork for the launch of SIP! in a BOX, however we still need $19,900 to build a safe and trusted e-commerce site, invest in marketing and advertising, and cover initial fees associated with warehouse rental and insurance.

Your contribution is the only way that we can launch this exciting new business venture.

What You Get

Your contribution is a BIG help for us AND there are awesome benefits in store for you as well! 


We are offering personalized wine consultations over the phone; an invitation to a special SIP donor wine and cheese party where we will sample some amazing wines together; and the VIP donors will receive their own private SIP event hosted by Crystal and Kelly.  Yes, the goal is to raise enough money to launch our dream project….but we also want you to love SIP! as much as we do!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute financially, you can help us in a really important way.  You can spread the word! We would appreciate it if you could post the link to this campaign page on your Facebook, twitter and Instagram accounts.  And if you know wine lovers who are not on social media but would like to contribute, please contact us and we will reach out to them directly via snail mail or a phone call.

Thanks in advance for helping us fund the expansion of SIP!

story:
Short Summary

As more and more people come online new ways of staying in contact with each other have surfaced.  The downside of this though is that although we are more virtually connected, we have become disconnected in our physical world. In many ways we have become disconnected from our own communities.  Our aim is to bring the human connection back by uniting local communities through sharing with the people around us while at the same time making the planet a greener place.

We want to create a global sharing platform for people to come together within their local communities and share things with each other. We will make this possible by providing a safe and trusted platform by connecting the current reach of Social Networking profiles, Product sharing, Feedback ratings and in turn develop a Personal Reputation rating system through a combination of Verified Profiles, Product sharing reviews, Feedback and eventually a marketplace where to share your expertise and services.

What is Tutums?

Tutums aims to offer a unique platform to allow individuals to contribute to a community of sharing. Through ID verification, reputation, and exchange metrics we aim to develop a platform where people we share things, time, and expertise while coming together and becoming a more active part of their offline communities. Tutums will encourage sharing by rewarding a profile the more it shares and offering a credit based system every time we share. We want to become an online community of exchange and personal interaction.

Tutums also aims to build personal online reputations and to eventually provide an exchange marketplace of expertise. It picks up where social media stops and completes the link that unites communities and makes us come together like never before.

The reason to crowd fund Tutums is because it not only helps to gauge interest in a project like this, but it gives an opportunity for funders to be part of the Tutums community from the very beginning. Having seen what a great community there is on Indiegogo supporting each other to make passion projects happen, this feels like the best way to do it. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support

We have been working on Tutums for the past few months and we've come a long way. But now we need your help. Your support will allow us to initiate the development of the software required to run Tutums efficiently in many different platforms and make Tutums available to you and to all the people who would like get involved in making a project of this magnitude work. Let's make our communities come together and let's come together.

What you get

In addition to the amazing perks listed you will be a funder of a project that we believe will change the world for the better. As an initial funder you will forever become an integral part of what made all of this happen!  Soon, Tutums will be connecting people to their communities like never before.

The Impact

At the very least, Tutums will create a new platforms for people to come together and share things and expertise with each other. However, if successful, this could revolutionize the world in many different ways. Having people interconnected like never before through Social Networking, Reputation metrics and our Goods/Expertise exchange together with peoples innate feeling to help each other could enable many millions of people to share and come together like never before.

Some other benefits include a decrease in packaging, more offline community interaction, more social integration, more community programs, Finally, even if only a fraction of the general public get to use Tutums, the mere action of introducing and facilitating these ideas/platform will encourage people to develop them further and achieve better more united world communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't support us with money, please tell your friends! Share this campaign and talk about it whenever you can. Follow us on Twitter (@Tutumscom) or Facebook.

story:
WHO WE ARE

Musana Jewelry is a non-profit organization that works with women in Lugazi, Uganda to design, produce, and sell beautiful jewelry, both in Uganda and in the United States. Musana identifies women with whom to work in at-risk populations, such as single mothers and women who are HIV-positive, who are in the greatest need and are determined to create a better life for themselves and their children.

Employment with Musana means developing self-reliance through consistent employment. A full-time job with Musana results in economic stability, the opportunity to gain marketable and transferable skills, and the option of supplemental English, health, and business education, which together lead to empowered individuals who become leaders in their community. Musana is a spark of opportunity that powers the growth of individuals, their families, and everyone else the artisans’ light touches. 

THIS CAMPAIGN

With the incredible opportunity for increased production over the past eight months, Musana has been able to hire more women and collaborate with more women’s groups in Lugazi Town. We want to expand our social services to meet this growth, so our holiday giving campaign is an effort to cover the funding costs for the first six months of 2013. 

THE IMPACT

Contributions will have a direct impact on improving the quality of life of the artisans Musana works with, including professional English instruction and a business development class of each artisan’s choice. It is the implementation of these programs that will have the truly profound effect of opening doors of opportunity for each woman and her children.

We have already seen shy, quiet artisans blossom into outgoing leaders with the help of English instruction and the confidence gained from building your own business. Even what seems like a relatively minor offering, such as being able to provide a two-hour workshop on contraception, can upend destructive local tall tales about the dangers of birth control and provide women with the tools to take control of their bodies and reproductive cycles. For Musana, providing social support for our artisans isn’t the icing on the cake, it is the fundamental reason for our existence.

WHAT WE NEED

With the six-month budget we’ve created, we plan to make vital improvements to our social services programs, in everything from hiring a highly trained English teacher, to subsidizing the artisans’ children’s school fees and providing internet access to improve computer literacy.

Musana’s 6-month wishlist:

English teacher training: $100

6-month English teacher salary: $192

English learning materials for 10 women: $50

6 months of internet: $720

 

6-month health instructor fee: $72

50 treated mosquito nets: $220

10 business training classes: $480

 

Nursery school fees for 6 children: $162

Primary school fees for 13 children: $367

Secondary schools fees for 2 children: $240

Subsidized university fees for 2 children: $680

                                            Total: $3,282

 

WHAT YOU GET

Your donation has a real impact on the lives of the Musana artisans, so we are offering small tokens of appreciation for your gift. Check out the sidebar to the right -->

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Spread the word! Share our fundraising campaign with your friends and family, on your social media outlets, and consider purchasing some jewelry as holiday gifts!

story:
Lambda Recovery Weekend

    Lambda was created over ten years ago as a way to bring men and women in the GLBT community together to celebrate their recovery.  There had always been retreats for sober men and women separately, and Lambda wanted to change that.
    Each year we work all year as a committee to fundraise and plan a very special three day long retreat at the beautiful Camp Stevens in Julian, California.  We offer a weekend full of learning, growth, spirituality, recovery, bonding, and creating new friendships.  We strive to create a weekend that is not only memorable, but creates life long friendships.  Each year we struggle to raise enough money to pull it off, sometimes reaching into our own pockets, but we always do somehow.  
    This year we need to replace some essential items that we used to borrow from another group, that we just don't have the funding for.  We are a very low budget group, and trying to raise money for additional items is difficult.  We need coolers, lighting, bins for storage, flags, flag poles, and misc. storage goods.  After we pay for the essentials we need we will use the additional monies for scholarships.
    Every year we invite people from a recovery home that we partner with to apply for a scholarship to attend the weekend retreat.  In exchange for the scholarship they volunteer their time to help make the retreat happen.  Every year we are able to grant scholarships to every person that applies.  We would love to be able to do that again this year.
  Personally Lambda has changed my life.  I have been a part of the organizing committee for three years, and the success of the retreat is incredible important to me.  Your contribution will help make that an attainable goal for me personally, and help allow a person, perhaps newly clean & sober, realize that life in sobriety can be amazing.  
   You can personally impact a persons sobriety by contributing to our campaign.  Please help us make Lambda 2013 the best retreat ever!

Christa O
President Lambda Recovery Weekend
story_txt:
Lambda Recovery Weekend
    Lambda was created over ten years ago as a way to bring men and women in the GLBT community together to celebrate their recovery.  There had always been retreats for sober men and women separately, and Lambda wanted to change that.
    Each year we work all year as a committee to fundraise and plan a very special three day long retreat at the beautiful Camp Stevens in Julian, California.  We offer a weekend full of learning, growth, spirituality, recovery, bonding, and creating new friendships.  We strive to create a weekend that is not only memorable, but creates life long friendships.  Each year we struggle to raise enough money to pull it off, sometimes reaching into our own pockets, but we always do somehow.  
    This year we need to replace some essential items that we used to borrow from another group, that we just don't have the funding for.  We are a very low budget group, and trying to raise money for additional items is difficult.  We need coolers, lighting, bins for storage, flags, flag poles, and misc. storage goods.  After we pay for the essentials we need we will use the additional monies for scholarships.
    Every year we invite people from a recovery home that we partner with to apply for a scholarship to attend the weekend retreat.  In exchange for the scholarship they volunteer their time to help make the retreat happen.  Every year we are able to grant scholarships to every person that applies.  We would love to be able to do that again this year.
  Personally Lambda has changed my life.  I have been a part of the organizing committee for three years, and the success of the retreat is incredible important to me.  Your contribution will help make that an attainable goal for me personally, and help allow a person, perhaps newly clean & sober, realize that life in sobriety can be amazing.

story:
Eastwick is an eco-conscious salon with a purpose. What does that mean? A few things…

Our Environment & Service Standard:

Eastwick is a salon designed with a literary theme. The aesthetic of which is an amalgamation of vintage apothecary meets English study. We will be a haven, a space where you will not only receive exceptional services, but have an experience that is tailored to you, our guest. Welcomed upon entering, you can expect a level of service akin to the Four Seasons set in an intimate, mom and pop atmosphere. All of our services will have an added value experience, compliments of Eastwick Salon. Receive a scalp massage prior to your haircut, warm towel foot wrap with color treatments and men’s services will come with a second rinse and warm towel face wrap. Should you prefer your coffee black with a morning service, enjoy quietly reading or want to be in and out, we will discover that about you, take note and apply it to your future services.

Our salon will use and sell industry leading products. Products that are environmentally friendly and produced by ethically responsible companies who share our vision for the future of our industry.

We also look forward to hosting annual customer appreciation events, during which we’ll have giveaways, complimentary add-on services, nibbles and cocktails. You’ll be celebrated! Inside our walls everyone is a VIP.

Local Partnerships & Philanthropy:

At Eastwick we believe in community and plan to support ours through local partnerships and philanthropy.

Let’s talk partnerships. So, we plan to serve alcohol. In doing so, why not help the local microbrew get established by pouring their beer? The same goes for carrying local wines. We will serve nibbles, at least on the weekends. Croissants from the local patisserie on a Saturday morning alongside a mimosa…not a bad way to start your day and service!

Aside from local partnerships, we are excited to have the opportunity to give back to our community. In house fund raising through raffles (where all proceeds go to a local charity or program) is just one small and simple approach. However, we will be hosting one or two annual events as well. For example, our team could provide back to school cuts for lower income kids. We’d promote the event for a month prior offering our clients a discount on retail purchases in exchange for school supplies. Working as a team to bring our skill set and services can benefit so many groups…Dress for Success, Ronald McDonald House and more!


What your support means to us and how we'll use it…

By contributing to Eastwick Salon, you are helping to establish a small business where we don’t just cater to you, but our community as well. You will enable a team of people who aren’t just talented, but committed to our culture and standards. Professionals who give a damn and give back. Folks ready to change the industry from the inside out and raise the next generation of stylists, leading by example and through mentorship.

In choosing the “flexible funding" option, our goal is to raise as much money as possible to be used as capital in obtaining a business loan. If we happen to exceed our goal, even better! While this campaign runs, we will utilize the funds we presently possess to begin forming our company. Our business lawyer will draft a partnership agreement, our logo will be developed, website created and business plan polished up and readied for presentation.


A little more about us...

Eastwick salon will have two co-owners. There’s myself, Robin Salas and my business partner. Out of respect for her current employer, and in an effort to keep her gainfully employed, she will remain behind the scenes for the time being. However, I can tell you all about her, what we bring to the table and how we will both contribute to running Eastwick Salon.

My Business Partner:

She has been in the industry since 2001, first working as a salon coordinator while getting her undergraduate degree. I met her in 2004, when she was the assistant manager at the salon where I completed my apprenticeship. She has since gone on to hold a Salon Manager/Director of Operations position at a very well respected salon here in Seattle. Along with continued education in regard to our industry and customer service, she is thoughtful, leads by example and has cultivated her own relationships with many respected individuals and vendors in our community.

Myself, Robin Salas:

 I have been in the industry since 2002, first as a salon coordinator and behind the chair since 2004 upon completing my apprenticeship. I've been an educator and mentor throughout my career, staying current on salon trends and technical skills by routinely furthering my own education. I am passionate about providing customized services geared toward each individual's needs and understand that superior customer service stems not only from cultivating relationships and building trust, but by providing outstanding services and exceeding expectations.

Division Of Responsibilities:

Robin Salas, Owner/Stylist/Marketing & Education Director

In addition to remaining behind the chair, I will assist in the general day to day running of the business. My duties will include, but are not limited to, making a name for Eastwick in the community through partnerships, events, social media and promotions. Supporting the new talent we bring into Eastwick Salon by establishing an apprenticeship program, as well as provide educational opportunities for our senior staff.

Business Partner, Owner/Director of Operations

Aside from developing and integrating our business culture and customer service standards, she will manage the day to day running of the business. This includes, but is not limited to, book keeping, inventory, sales, ordering and the hiring and training of our guest services team.


What's in store for our staff...

It is our hope to create a space that serves our guests, community and staff. We plan to employ 5-7 hair stylists and two guest services coordinators. Through employment with Eastwick, staff can receive flexible vacation benefits, enjoy extended holiday closures, take advantage of a retirement plan and education credits. Of course our ultimate goal...Eastwick's ability to provide healthcare!


The Nuts & Bolts…

Milestones:

Secure Final Funding and Lease Signing, December 2015

Build Out, February 01, 2016

Ideally this is when construction on our commercial space will begin.

Initial Hiring Of Staff, March 2016

Begin process of interviewing and hiring three stylists set to start when Eastwick opens, 5/3/16.

Salon "Soft" Open, May 03, 2016

Open doors and begin service. We will have four full time stylists including owner Robin Salas.

Second Wave of Hiring, May 31, 2016

Start interviewing to bring on two additional stylists and a part time Guest Services Coordinator to begin employment last week of June/July 1st.

Third Wave of Hiring, August 15, 2016

Start process of hiring 1-2 more stylists to begin employment mid-October filling all positions available.

Grand Opening "Harvest" Party, October 29, 2016

Celebrating our endeavors! This will be an event where Eastwick Salon reaches out to our community and clients introducing them to our concept, intentions and mission with a fun family friendly Halloween theme.


We appreciate you taking the time to check us out & THANK YOU, for your consideration and participation! PLEASE share our campaign!


Feel free to check out Eastwick's Pinterest page at, https://www.pinterest.com/salasrobin/eastwick-salon/.

story:
Gold Crush is the creation of a group of climbers who want to see a more active climbing community in Nevada County and believe that having access to an indoor gym is the solution. Not only will Gold Crush cater to seasoned climbers, it will also teach kids responsibility, leadership, and sound climbing skills.

In 2015, Sierra Nevada Climbing Co-op began to pave the path with community meetings and outreach events. In order to move this vision forward we began looking at spaces for a climbing gym. In the spring of 2016, a space was acquired and that dream is now becoming a reality.

The phenomenal turnout at SNCC’s first preview event in June made it very clear that access to indoor climbing was shared by many more than our small core group of members and volunteers. Sierra Nevada Climbing Co-op is committed to building Gold Crush, but we cannot do so without contributions from people like you.

Our approach to business is collaborative and community focused. In the future, we will offer employee discounts for local businesses and will extend opportunities for education and fun to everyone in the area. This is not just another climbing gym. This is about engaging our community through our youth and retailer programs. We hope to leverage the large pool of talent that the area has to offer.  

With the help of your contribution, Gold Crush will be able to open its doors as the only public climbing gym in Nevada County. It is important that we not only build a place for people to come, but that we also provide an encouraging atmosphere for members and guests, including structurally sound walls and a clean environment. 

The $30,000 that we need to raise during the Indie-Go-Go campaign will go toward start-up business, programming to start classes and establish a youth program, and construction costs. With your help, Gold Crush climbing gym will be able to create what many in the area have been dreaming of – an indoor climbing gym that stands as an engaging, and positive space for everyone.
